text: We believe TEMP.Mana, a Chinese cyber espionage group, is linked to infrastructure spoofing domains of at least two U.S. chemical manufacturers. Similar activity suspected of being tied to TEMP.Mana reinforces the risk to the chemical sector and related industries.

Chinese cyber espionage operators modified the software packages of a legitimate vendor, NetSarang Computer, allowing access to a broad range of industries and institutions that include financial services, transportation, telecommunications, energy, media, academic, retail, and gaming. The malicious actors embedded a backdoor named SHADOWPAD, which can access network data and download additional malware. Based on shared communications infrastructure and similar targeting and tactics, FireEye Threat Intelligence assesses this activity is related to a Chinese espionage team that previously targeted a gaming company in 2015.

GREF Team is an innovative China-nexus cyber espionage operator that focuses on targeting energy, video game development studios, and high-tech companies in the U.S., South Korea, the Netherlands, Italy, France, and Japan. The group leverages a large library of malware tools, compromised digital certificates, and exploits. Besides being linked to a common supplier shared with other Chinese cyber espionage groups, GREF Team is believed to distribute its tools to other distinct China-based actors.

FireEye Threat Intelligence uncovered GREF Team reusing a sender address from 2016 to target a European cryptocurrency exchange. GREF Team leveraged .NET malware that beacons to an IP address belonging to a South Korean University. This is the first time FireEye Threat Intelligence has uncovered GREF Team targeting financial entities, but it is consistent with our assessment that the team is involved in both financially motivated activity and cyber espionage on behalf of Chinese government interests.

FireEye Threat Intelligence analyzed data sourced from a command and control (C&C) server running an application named "Werka," which is used by TrickBot for dynamic webinject administration and delivery. The Werka server delivers unique web injection code based on the presence of different gtags, or campaign identifiers, within requests made to the server. The manner in which this system operates suggests that each gtag value is associated with a different TrickBot customer. FireEye Threat Intelligence has identified and clustered a number of TrickBot gtag values found in the configuration of this system and has further found evidence to suggest that some associated TrickBot customers may be actively using other banking malware families, including Corebot, Danabot, Emotet, Gootkit, IcedID, Nymaim, TinyNuke, Ursnif, and Zeus Panda.

FireEye Threat Intelligence discovered dozens of irregularities in the domain resolutions of government and commercial websites in the Middle East, North Africa, and Europe. Since 2017, DNS records were altered, and fraudulent Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) certificates were created for more than 100 domains in order to redirect and intercept website traffic and steal valid credentials and emails. FireEye Threat Intelligence has been unable to attribute these unauthorized changes to a tracked group; however, the targeting and limited technical evidence are consistent with Iranian actors. It is also likely that more than one actor has used this technique.

FireEye Threat Intelligence has observed evidence of an actor(s) leveraging GitHub to host a variety of malware for campaigns that appear to be targeting entities in Russia for financial gain. Despite recent reporting indicating that these campaigns are distributing Buhtrap, we have not observed direct evidence of Buhtrap payloads being delivered in these operations. We anticipate that this actor(s) will continue conducting operations for at least the near term. However, due to the variety of different malware families these operations have employed, it is possible that this actor(s) will adopt additional malware variants in future operations.

Continued examination revealed multiple distinct clusters within the previously reported DNS manipulation activity. Cluster A uses phishing and TWOTONE malware, and Cluster B appears to use web exploits and penetration testing frameworks to gain initial access to victim networks. Actors responsible for Cluster B interrupted operations after an emergency directive was published by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) on Jan. 22, 2019, but we cannot definitively say that this publication caused the change in operations. However, FireEye Threat Intelligence discovered Cluster B victims leveraging new infrastructure since then.

FireEye devices detected and blocked a likely Iranian group using a compromised email account to target a Lebanese insurance company using TWOTONE malware and newly registered command and control (C&C) infrastructure. The compromised email account belongs to a Lebanese insurance company which experienced DNS hijacking activity Nov. 28, 2018. FireEye Threat Intelligence found a related phishing document impersonating a UK university and domains spoofing an Indian outsourcing firm.

In late March 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed UPS- and invoice-themed campaigns delivering Emotet via links leading to ZIP archives containing macro-laden Word documents or JavaScript. This is a departure from its historical tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs); most commonly, campaigns have leveraged macro document attachments or links leading to macro documents. FireEye Threat Intelligence also observed changes in the way Emotet communicates through HTTP POST requests with its command and control (C&C) servers. These changes were likely made to evade host and network-based detection mechanisms, although it would be easy for security product vendors to adapt to these changes.

A supply chain compromise first reported in March 2019 distributed CRACKSHOT and DEADEYE downloaders primarily to victims in Southeast Asia. We surmise the incident is linked to similar previously reported supply chain compromises affecting entities in East Asia, although the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) demonstrate a greater effort to evade detection and hinder analysis when compared to the older campaigns.

FireEye Threat Intelligence has been tracking a fast-flux bulletproof hosting infrastructure internally named "Fluxxy" (aka DarkCloud) that has been active since at least late 2009.The actor(s) associated with the bulletproof hosting service use the moniker "Ccweb" and have advertised the bulletproof hosting service on exploit.in since 2010, with the notable addition of fast-flux in 2012. The actor "Sollhost" is believed to be a verified reseller of Fluxxy offering the service under the name of "Sollhost bulletproof hosting." FireEye Threat Intelligence has observed significant interest in Fluxxy by a large number of actors. The related infrastructure has been leveraged for various types of malicious activity, including numerous malware operations, phishing sites, and card shops; we assess with high confidence that actors will continue using this service.

FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a cluster of activity that began in April 2019 and continued through June 2019 that leveraged web-based attacks including the SharePoint vulnerability CVE-2019-0604 to target financial institutions in Turkey and Southeast Asia. Based on overlaps in infrastructure and targeting, we assess with low confidence this campaign is affiliated with TEMP.Shadow (aka EmpireMonkey) and is likely financially motivated. We anticipate the actors responsible for this operation will continue targeting financial institutions for the foreseeable future; however, the actors may shift at least some tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) in future operations.

In mid-July 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed multiple files that were being used to deliver the COOLPANTS backdoor. While we have not yet identified any phishing emails associated with this campaign, there is some indication this activity impacted financial institutions based in Latvia and Panama. Based on the use of overlapping tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), we assess with low confidence that the recent KAYSLICE/COOLPANTS campaign can be attributed to TEMP.MetaStrike (aka Cobalt Group).

Since June 7, 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence has observed a complete cessation of Emotet-related spam distribution activity. The inactivity of Emotet distribution operations is supported by evidence observed across the FireEye sensor network and active monitoring of the Emotet botnet. The cause for this current cessation of activity is unclear, and it is not known whether this period of inactivity will lead to a permanent change in Emotet operations, though we continue to proactively monitor the situation.

A software error in GPS receivers caused an outage of Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Broadcast (ADS-B) aircraft tracking systems, grounding 400 flights. With a federal mandate for ADS-B adoption approaching in January 2020, we consider the known vulnerabilities in the system. FireEye Threat Intelligence views the current risk of ADS-B attacks as low, given their complexity, but warns that inexpensive hardware and broader adoption could make the system a target for motivated attackers. This incident highlights the need to consider the robustness and resilience of critical positioning, navigation, and timing systems and communication infrastructure in the aviation sector.

On May 14, 2019, FireEye devices detected spear-phishing emails attempting to direct victims to Dropbox folders to deliver the TAILCOAT payload. The emails were sent to employees at several European missions to Palestine and related diplomatic entities in the region and leveraged Palestinian-themed lure content. While attribution is unclear, tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) and targeting is consistent with previously reported Molerats Team activity.

On July 12, 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a phishing campaign that delivered the COOLPANTS backdoor using financial transaction-themed lures. The emails in this campaign included indicators and targeting typical of past suspected TEMP.Splinter campaigns and delivered a COOLPANTS payload that used command and control (C&C) infrastructure overlapping with a past suspected TEMP.MetaStrike campaign. While COOLPANTS is believed to be private to TEMP.MetaStrike, this malware has been delivered in multiple previous campaigns that exhibit delivery methods and targeting characteristic of TEMP.Splinter. Plausible scenarios that may explain this include TEMP.Splinter acting as a delivery service, all observed activity being carried out by TEMP.MetaStrike, or intermittent cooperation between the two groups.

In May 2019, FireEye devices detected and blocked a spear-phishing campaign likely targeting Ukrainian government entities distributing the ARMEDCLOUD malware attributed to TEMP.Armageddon. Additional samples and related infrastructure were subsequently uncovered. This newest version of ARMEDCLOUD contains anti-forensic features.

After a brief cessation of Qakbot activity in early July 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed Qakbot activity resume on July 16 and incorporate an updated version of the password grabber module. The latest version of the password grabber module includes debug strings that reveal names of internal functions and the name of the module itself (plugin_passgrabber).One of the most notable aspects of the update is the inclusion of two embedded URLs that were seen leading to the download of a version of Mimikatz that appears to be unique to Qakbot.

Beginning on July 18, 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed Amadey campaigns that closely resembled previous Chanitor campaigns and delivered Cobalt Strike Beacon, Pony, SendSafe, and Ursnif. Based on multiple overlaps in the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) used throughout these campaigns, we have high confidence that at least one of the actors associated with the Chanitor distribution network has begun using AMADEY malware in campaigns as a replacement for Chanitor. While these campaigns appear to be related to prior Chanitor campaigns, there were notable difference beyond its replacement with AMADEY that suggest the actors behind this operation are experimenting with new TTPs.

Spear-phishing campaigns were identified targeting U.S. think tanks and federally funded research and development centers (FFRDCs) with LATEOP malware in May and June 2019. This activity is likely linked to previous spear-phishing campaigns targeting similar victims during the past year, and conducted by the same distinct actor, although attribution remains unclear. Based on lure content, targeting patterns, and tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) overlap, we believe this activity is likely conducted by an actor with a North Korean nexus.

In late July 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed a campaign using various delivery mechanisms to deliver KAYSLICE and COOLPANTS. Observed recipients included individuals at financial organizations based in Russia and Slovakia. Based on the use of overlapping tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), we assess with moderate confidence that the recent KAYSLICE/COOLPANTS campaign can be attributed to TEMP.MetaStrike (aka Cobalt Group).

On July 25, 2019, City Power Johannesburg announced that their information technology (IT) systems were infected with a ransomware virus that encrypted their "databases, applications and networks. " The attack on Johannesburg-based City Power prevented customers on pay-as-you-go plans from purchasing electricity. FireEye Threat Intelligence has recently observed various cases of ransomware infections on IT systems resulting in disruptions or outages to production despite no impact to operational technology (OT) networks (19-00012368). City Power's incident is the first instance we have observed where customers lost access to energy as a result of malware infections in corporate networks. We suggest that organizations with high-availability requirements evaluate their safety and business risks related to ransomware attacks.

Security researchers identified 11 vulnerabilities in the VxWorks real-time operating system (RTOS) developed by Wind River. The collection of vulnerabilities is dubbed "Urgent/11." RTOS have specialized kernels that minimize interruptions to critical system processes. VxWorks is the most common RTOS and can be found in embedded systems used in a wide variety of industries, including aerospace and defense, automotive, consumer electronics, industrial automation, medical devices, and network/computer infrastructure. Asset owners are encouraged to apply the latest patches released by Wind River. Alternative mitigations, such as firewall rules, intrusion detection signatures, or OS-version upgrades, can be deployed as countermeasures in the absence of patches.

FireEye devices blocked the attempted download of a SOGU payload at a Hong Kong-based media organization. Based on infrastructure overlap and similarities in tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), we believe this activity is likely related to previous Chinese espionage operations leveraging SOGU and HIGHNOON malware. We note that this activity will likely continue in the short to medium term and that media and civil society organizations in the region remain at risk of targeting with SOGU malware.

FireEye Threat Intelligence uncovered a malicious profiling script on the website of an Armenian think tank in June 2019. The website redirects to a second compromised domain hosting a WITCHCOVEN profiling script. WITCHCOVEN has been used by Russia-nexus Turla since 2014 to collect detailed web browser information and install a persistent tracking cookie. The compromised domain also hosted a sample of the new WHIPSNAP backdoor.

FireEye technical analysts examined two APT32 archives leveraging Singapore conference-themed filenames and decoy documents to target unknown victims. At least one sample was hosted on Dropbox and likely delivered through a malicious link embedded in a phishing email. Following victim initialization of the executable contained in the archive, the infection process leads to installation of a FREIGHTBOX dropper and a BEACON payload.

FireEye Threat Intelligence analyzed a malicious macro document targeting a U.S.-based water and power utility company in late July 2019. The unknown threat actor leveraged skilled social engineering techniques and LOOKBACK malware. The macro document bears superficial similarities to public FireEye Threat Intelligence reporting on UPPERCUT activity. Entities in the utilities sector are likely at risk of targeting in the short- to medium-term and should remain vigilant.

A newly identified downloader, referred to by FireEye Threat Intelligence as BULLZLINK, demonstrates a number of overlaps with malware developed and offered by badbullzvenom. During July 2019, two campaigns were identified using this downloader, including a NETWIRE campaign attributed to TEMP.Splinter and a likely SQUIDSLEEP/SQUIDGATE campaign that has not yet been attributed to a specific threat actor group. Based upon these observations, we assess with moderate confidence that badbullzvenom is continuing to develop new tools for use by financially motivated threat actors.

In August 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified campaigns leveraging a modified version of SmokeLoader that bypasses the normal SmokeLoader pay-per-update business model. This modified version of the malware has been patched by editing existing binaries to communicate with updated command and control (C&C) URLs. While we have not yet observed any actors publicly advertising this modified version of SmokeLoader for sale, it is plausible that actors could sell this version of the malware for significantly less than the original version of SmokeLoader.

During a compromise of a hospitality organization, which we attribute to FIN7, the attackers deployed various malicious payloads, including CARBANAK, BABYMETAL, and the PILLOWMINT point-of-sale (POS) malware. Notably, in this incident, FIN7 leveraged a seemingly compromised email account belonging one of the victim's suppliers to send a password-protected GRIFFON document to a restaurant manager. FIN7's shift to engaging in third-party compromise attacks marks a significant evolution in the group's operations and the manner in which organizations need to protect themselves against their attacks.

Since the December 2018 indictment of multiple APT10 actors, monitoring of numerous attack surfaces, sensitive-source feeds, public repositories, and open-source reporting has not resulted in the detection of new APT10 activity. Based on prior operational characteristics, we continue to assess with low confidence that the group has reduced operational visibility and will return after a period of dormancy. However, the actors themselves may have been reassigned or relieved from their contracts. Operators previously associated with APT10 may have returned as part of different APT missions working on behalf of the People's Republic of China Ministry of State Security (MSS). APT10 was known for having shifted over to publicly available tools and either using them as-is or only slightly modifying them. Their last activity before the indictment was largely QUASSARRAT, BEACON, and UPPERCUT. Previously, each time that APT10 has reemerged after a lull, the group has largely shifted over to new sets of public or shared tools.

South Asian government entities were targeted with BREEZESUGAR malware in a spear-phishing campaign on June 12, 2019.Although attribution is unclear, we have previously seen similar activity in campaigns leveraging EVILNUGGET, which we believe is used by Chinese actors. Governments and military entities in South Asia remain at risk of targeting by this actor and BREEZESUGAR malware.

In August 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a campaign in which malicious actors targeted customers of two Mexican banks with a customized variant of the KL Remota banking malware. Based on overlaps in the attacker infrastructure, we assess with high confidence that this recent campaign was conducted by a Mexican threat actor who has been active for more than four years. There are multiple indications that Brazilian malware developer(s) provided the Mexican threat actor with a customized variant of the KL Remota for use in operations targeting Mexican financial institutions. The relationship highlights Brazilian malware developers' interest in broadening the scope of their operations and their willingness to engage actors or groups from other countries for monetary gains.

FireEye Threat Intelligence recently observed a malicious email campaign targeting multiple organizations across North America and Europe and delivering FLAWEDAMMYYY payloads. This activity has overlaps with a financially motivated actor dubbed TEMP.Warlock, which has been seen at multiple intrusions where we have attributed the latter-stage operations to FIN6 and FIN7. While the targeted organizations observed in this recent spam campaign do not resemble traditional financial, retail, or hospitality targets, we consider this event significant because of recent trends in which relatively sophisticated financially motivated threat actors are pivoting to ransomware and extortion to monetize their network intrusion efforts.

FireEye detected and blocked a suspected APT28 phishing operation that targeted an Eastern European Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA). The malicious phishing messages were delivered with EYEGRAB malware, a GoLang variant of BASESHOW that takes screenshots of a victim's desktop and can accept commands from a command and control (C&C) server. FireEye assesses with moderate confidence that this operation is attributed to APT28-based technical analysis and targeting consistent with previous operations.

APT41, a cyber espionage operation aligned with Chinese interests, is using MESSAGETAP malware to parse and log SMS data at a telecommunications company. MESSAGETAP leverages a keyword list to identify messages of interest, including those related to internal security issues and military ranks. The campaign exemplifies Chinese espionage efforts to collect information from further upstream in global network traffic flow instead of at the level of targeted organizations or individual end users.

In mid-August 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified multiple files that were being used to deliver the COOLPANTS backdoor. While we have not yet identified any phishing emails associated with this campaign, there is some indication the activity impacted an organization in Moldova, although targeting was likely broader than observed. Based on the use of overlapping tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), we assess with low confidence that the recent KAYSLICE/COOLPANTS campaign can be attributed to TEMP.MetaStrike (aka Cobalt Group).

An unidentified actor targeted coalition forces, media outlets, government entities, and humanitarian aid organizations in a spear-phishing campaign in late July 2019. The emails leveraged "Youth in Afghanistan"-related lure content and contained a malicious Word document with additional decoy content to deliver a variant of xRAT malware to the targeted systems. We currently lack sufficient information to attribute this activity to a specific actor.

FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a North Korean defector-themed spear-phishing campaign likely targeting entities and individuals with an interest in inter-Korean border issues with Windows and Android variants of DOGCALL malware. Based on overlaps in tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), the use of DOGCALL malware, and the targeting of individuals with an interest in the cross-border conflict, we assess with high confidence that this activity is conducted by APT37. Entities and researchers with an interest in inter-Korean border issues remain at risk of targeting with DOGCALL malware in the short to medium term.

In mid-August 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified malicious URLs hosting HTA files that, if navigated to, resulted in the download of PowerShell Empire; links to these HTA files were posted on a Canadian stock forum messaging board. Based on overlaps in the attacker infrastructure, regional targeting, and the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) used throughout this recent activity and prior FIN10 campaigns, we have high confidence this activity can be attributed to FIN10. This recent campaign suggests that FIN10 continues to employ familiar TTPs, and we anticipate that these operations will persist in the near term.

Screenshots leaked in June 2019 suggest Lebanese entities were targeted with DUALTONE malware, a .NET variant of TWOTONE, called Karkoff by its author. Submissions of DUALTONE samples to a public malware repository suggest a global port operator in Lebanon was likely also targeted with DUALTONE malware in March 2019. Based on targeting consistencies, samples uploaded to public malware repositories, and technical indicators, we assess with high confidence that APT34 is responsible for this activity and that related entities remain at risk of DUALTONE malware targeting.

FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a botnet panel named "X-Key" on a malicious IP server. The command and control (C&C) server hosts the XKEYLOG malware, a keylogger that is also capable of taking screenshots. Among the files obtained from the sever is a screenshot of a human-machine interface (HMI) used to monitor Sulphur Recovery Units (SRUs). We believe the actor inadvertently accessed the HMI while searching for point-of-sale (POS) systems to facilitate credit card theft. The identification of this HMI screenshot highlights the continued accessibility of such systems by relatively unsophisticated threat actors. We recommend that companies conduct regular scans of their IP ranges to determine if any of their control systems are directly connected to the internet.

The Emotet botnet ceased its spam operations and distribution of secondary payloads between early June 2019 and mid-August 2019. Beginning on Aug. 21, 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed several Emotet controllers delivering modules to existing bots. These controllers had been seen in previous Emotet operations. New Emotet samples were identified on Sept. 9, 2019, that contained new command and control (C&C) infrastructure. FireEye Threat Intelligence has not yet identified any malicious email campaigns distributing Emotet, however, the presence of new infrastructure further suggests the Emotet botnet will return to full operation in the near future.

In July 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a server hosting a collection of tools, including newly identified variants of two point-of-sale (POS) malware families, each of which were previously associated with only one distinct threat actor group, FIN7 or FIN8. While the exact nature of the relationship between the groups and their tools may be more easily assessed as activity continues, the presence of both FIN7 and FIN8 tools on the same server suggests that either some tools are not unique to the respective threat groups or some overlap exists between their associated actors. The server also contained a newly identified Ursnif variant we are tracking as SAIGON and two new malware families we are tracking as FLIPSWITCH and WOOLSOCKS. Analysis of the malware is ongoing and will be updated as additional information is uncovered. This observed activity is significant because it provides evidence of business relationships among criminal groups, which may enable the groups to attain higher levels of technical sophistication or to tackle larger projects.

FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a different variant of SCRAPMINT that has no exfiltration mechanism, does not communicate over the network, and expects a filename to be passed as an argument. This variant of SCRAPMINT was hosted on a server that also hosted multiple other point-of-sale (POS) malware and public tools. FireEye Threat Intelligence was able to gain additional insights into the threat actors' post-compromise activities preceding the deployment of SCRAPMINT from an XKEYLOG server. The modification of SCRAPMINT allows for smaller and less complex malware and gives actors the ability to deploy a separate exfiltration tool more suitable for a given victim environment.

FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a BIODISK binary designed to compromise fingerprint-secured USB drives and may be used to infiltrate air-gapped networks. The BIODISK binary targeted a government and defense entity in the Asia-Pacific region. While attribution is unclear, the threat actor is highly sophisticated and likely conducted extensive reconnaissance against the victim environment.

In late August 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified two waves of a phishing campaign that delivered KAYSLICE and COOLPANTS and leveraged domains spoofing Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication (SWIFT) and the European Central Bank. Based on overlaps in infrastructure and observed tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), we assess with moderate confidence that this recent activity can be attributed to TEMP.MetaStrike. The most recent campaign employed two new delivery TTPs that were not observed in previous TEMP.MetaStrike campaigns, including the use of weaponized browser updates and IMG files to deliver malicious JavaScript and LNK files. The changes are consistent with our previous assessments that TEMP.MetaStrike regularly shifts its TTPs to remain undetected and increase the effectiveness of its campaigns.

In August 2019, Belarusian media outlets reported that a rogue electronic device was found under the server room of a paper mill in Svetlogorsk, Belarus. The device is allegedly capable of remotely damaging manufacturing processes and server equipment by causing a short circuit. Sources claim the device was planted by CAMCE, a Chinese contractor constructing the mill. CAMCE is also accused of extracting license keys from servers, deleting control logic, and dismantling a turbine control cable. While our independent research sheds doubt on the accuracy of this reporting, the incident highlights the unusually high risk sometimes posed by corporate entities and insiders. Organizations should audit third parties to detect potential illegitimate activity, particularly when contracts involve industrial safety and reliability design features.

FireEye Threat Intelligence observed a spear-phishing campaign targeting entities in the virtual currency exchange sector with SOGU malware in June 2019. The activity leveraged Windows Control Panel objects to download and execute a SOGU payload on the victim's system. Similar entities in the virtual currency exchange sector and the financial services industry remain at risk of targeting by SOGU malware in the short to medium term.

In late August 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed an email campaign delivering PACKETSPLIT and WSHRAT. The campaign appeared to impact financial services organizations based in Southeast Asia, although targeting may have been broader than what was directly observed. We have high confidence that this recent campaign can be attributed to TEMP.Splinter based on overlaps in tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) with prior campaigns.

DanaBot is a modular banking Trojan that was first seen in May 2018. FireEye Threat Intelligence previously reported that the malware appears to be operated by one group that likely has multiple customers responsible for its distribution. We have high confidence that JimmBee's private banking malware advertised in mid-April 2018 is DanaBot based on multiple similarities in the malware and recent claims made by other threat actors that JimmBee sells DanaBot. The frequent updates made to DanaBot, the moderate interest shown from other actors in the malware, and the DanaBot campaigns we have observed up to this point suggest it will be used to facilitate malicious operations for at least the near term.

In August 2019, media outlets reported on a cryptomining incident at a nuclear power plant in Ukraine. Some reports suggested that the cryptocurrency mining farm used operational technology (OT) "supercomputers" and exposed information related to physical security. FireEye Threat Intelligence assesses with high confidence that the cryptocurrency mining farm was limited to employee-owned equipment not connected to OT systems. We posit the possibility that the incident exposed OT systems to unnecessary risk. The incident highlights the risks associated with rogue devices and malicious insiders. We stress the importance of device authentication and management controls, such as the separation of duties and internal job rotation.

On Sept. 4, 2019, the North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC) released a "Lessons Learned" report providing additional details regarding a denial-of-service (DoS) incident that impacted a U.S. utility on March 5, 2019. The incident resulted from the exploitation of known vulnerabilities in firewall web interfaces. While the outages resulted in no major impacts to energy generation, the incident highlights that internet-connected perimeter devices—even in low-impact bulk electric systems (BES)—may expose networks to disruption or degradation threats. FireEye Threat Intelligence suggests that asset owners avoid internet connectivity for perimeter devices whenever feasible, configure firewalls to deny any traffic not explicitly allowed, and perform regular vulnerability assessments.

An ongoing spear-phishing campaign distributing the SOURCANDLE downloader has been targeting Japanese chemicals manufacturers since July 2019. Although we have no indications of direct intellectual property (IP) theft, cyber espionage operations targeting chemicals manufacturers may enable strategic decision making, especially amidst unstable market conditions.

The Emotet botnet ceased its spam operations and distribution of secondary payloads between early June 2019 and mid-August 2019. While we began to see limited Emotet activity beginning on Aug. 21, 2019, no spam campaigns had been identified. On Sept. 16, 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed Emotet resume spamming using both German and English lures. Additionally, we identified secondary TrickBot and Ursnif (Gozi-ISFB) payloads being downloaded. There does not appear to be any notable evolution to the botnet's tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), although we are continuing to analyze the recently observed Emotet executables to identify any changes.

The Emotet botnet ceased its spam operations and distribution of secondary payloads between early June 2019 and mid-August 2019. While we began to see limited Emotet activity beginning on Aug. 21, 2019, no spam campaigns had been identified. Additionally, we identified secondary TrickBot and Ursnif (Gozi-ISFB) payloads being downloaded. There does not appear to be any notable evolution to the botnet's tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), although we are continuing to analyze the recently observed Emotet executables to identify any changes.

Incidental malware remains a threat for Windows-based operational technology (OT) assets when left unprotected. FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a large number of OT binaries infected from portable executable (PE) malware. While there is no indication that this activity was specifically targeting OT systems, incidental outbreaks can have serious implications for OT environments. Asset owners should prioritize implementing prevention methods and controls to avert infections in their environments and ensure backups are captured and tested for process critical assets.

In late August 2019, the actor "dihlofoss" posted a complaint against another actor using the handle "shitscrazy." According to this complaint, shitscrazy owed a significant amount of debt for "cashed transfers. "This recent complaint, as well as shitscrazy's other observed activities within the underground community, provides some evidence that shitscrazy has provided cashout services for the operators of the Dridex malware. Actor shitscrazy has shown consistent interest in multiple types of malicious activity within the past several years, and we expect this actor's activities will continue to pose a threat to organizations in diverse sectors and regions.

The SAKABOTA toolkit has targeted Middle Eastern government entities since late 2017 and may be used by an actor loosely tied to APT34. SAKABOTA is a modular .NET toolkit capable of leveraging additional payloads such as DIEZEN, SAKABOTA Eye, HISOKA, and LINKHIDE malware. Organizations that have previously been targeted by Iran-nexus espionage operations and government, financial, and consulting entities in the Middle East remain at high risk of targeting.

In mid-September 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a phishing campaign delivering KAYSLICE and COOLPANTS malware that used XZ archive attachments containing either a JavaScript dropper or RTF downloader document. This campaign involved tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) that have previously been used in both TEMP.MetaStrike (aka Cobalt Group) and TEMP.Splinter campaigns. Notably, this is the first campaign that involved the targeting of Russian organizations where TTPs associated with TEMP.Splinter have been observed.

A suspected APT33 campaign leveraged spoofed U.S. defense contractor domains to deliver POSHC2 and KOADIC malware. The domain naming conventions and an associated webpage advertise career opportunities in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, with specific defense contractors. While the precise method of distribution of the suspected payloads remains unclear, a trusted third party has reported targeted emails associated with the domains.

A cyber espionage operation targeted a possible Kazakhstan entity with a malicious document that exploits CVE-2017-11882.Following successful exploitation, the sample drops WHITEFERRY malware, a reconnaissance tool that appears to target systems on an air-gapped networks. WHITEFERRY's air-gapped design suggests that the program could potentially be used against secure government, military, or financial organizations.

Recent open-source reports describe new MANGOPUNCH activity targeting U.S. military personnel and Saudi Arabian information technology (IT) providers. FireEye Threat Intelligence observations, in conjunction with public disclosures, reveal a number of samples suggesting renewed Iran-nexus operations using MANGOPUNCH. While we have previously seen APT35 use MANGOPUNCH during intrusions in 2017, FireEye Threat Intelligence is withholding attribution at this time until more evidence becomes available.

FireEye Threat Intelligence  identified multiple modified TRITON framework executables uploaded to a malware analysis sandbox in September 2019. While the modified executables were apparently uploaded by a researcher, their release confirms our assessment and highlights that publicly available TRITON code can be used to develop new tools for intrusion. Targeted industrial control system (ICS) attack frameworks—like TRITON—can be difficult to scale because of the unique design of networks for different organizations. However, we highlight that access to this improved code can serve as a blueprint for future ICS attack frameworks.

During several recent incident response engagements, FireEye Mandiant investigators uncovered new tools in FIN7's malware arsenal and kept pace as the global criminal operators attempted new evasion techniques. The first of FIN7's new tools is BOOSTWRITE, an in-memory-only dropper that decrypts embedded payloads using an encryption key retrieved from a remote server at runtime. One of the analyzed BOOSTWRITE variants contained two payloads: CARBANAK and RDFSNIFFER. RDFSNIFFER appears to have been developed to tamper with the NCR Corporation "Aloha Command Center" client. While these incidents also included FIN7's typical and long-used toolsets, such as CARBANAK and BABYMETAL, the introduction of new tools and techniques provides further evidence FIN7 is continuing to evolve in response to security enhancements.

On Sept. 30, 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed bots associated with TrickBot and IcedID receive identical commands to download a file. This file appeared to be a variant of the GlobeImpsoter ransomware based on publicly reported tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) associated with this ransomware family. The activity highlights a recent trend in which a rising number of threat actors have incorporated ransomware into their operations presumably to diversify monetization tactics and achieve higher profits.

Throughout late September and early October 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed multiple phishing campaigns delivering KAYSLICE and COOLPANTS malware. Based on overlaps in infrastructure and observed targeting, we assess with moderate confidence that this recent activity can be attributed to TEMP.MetaStrike. We also identified overlaps between the TTPs used in these recent campaigns and an unattributed COOLPANTS campaign that occurred in mid-September 2019.

FireEye Threat Intelligence uncovered a modified sample of the Russia-nexus Turla Team XTRANS malware, dubbed NETTRANS, likely targeting Brazilian entities in August 2019. Like XTRANS, NETTRANS communicates via encoded JPEG files sent via email for command and control (C&C). It is unclear whether NETTRANS is intended to supplement or replace XTRANS and under what conditions each might be deployed.

Malware researchers have come across a new Remote Access Trojan (RAT) that uses a novel technique to evade detection on corporate networks by fetching malicious PowerShell commands stored inside a domain's DNS TXT records.
 The malware, nicknamed DNSMessenger, was first detected by a security researcher named Simpo.
 The RAT came to the attention of the Cisco Talos security team after Simpo discovered a Base64 string that translated back to "SourceFireSux," SourceFire being one of Cisco's corporate security products.

 Welp, someone doesn't like SourceFire pic.twitter.com/NzuGXZ0WgC
— simpo (@Simpo13) February 24, 2017
 This wasn't up to Cisco's liking, and its researchers decided to investigate further. What they found was a malware that was more advanced than they ever expected.

A new CryptoMix, or CryptFile2, variant called Revenge has been discovered by Broad Analysis that is being distributed via the RIG exploit kit.   This variant contains many similarities to its predecessor CryptoShield, which is another CryptoMix variant, but includes some minor changes that are described below.
 As a note, in this article I will be referring to this infection as the Revenge Ransomware as that will most likely be how the victim's refer to it. It is important to remember, though, that this ransomware is not a brand new infection, but rather a new version of the CryptoMix ransomware family.
 How Victim's Become Infected with the Revenge Ransomware
 Both BroadAnalysis.com and Brad Duncan, of Malware-Traffic-Analysis.net, have seen Revenge being distributed through web sites that have been hacked so that the RIG Exploit Kit javascript is added pages on the site.

WhatsApp and Telegram have patched their respective web clients against a common security flaw discovered by researchers from Israeli firm Check Point, a security issue that would have allowed an attacker to take over user accounts and spy on conversations or steal user account data.
 According to researchers, the entry point was an attacker's ability to upload and send malicious code hidden inside HTML files.
 Both WhatsApp and Telegram would show a preview image for these links, making users believe they were accessing a video or image.
 Exploit granted attackers access to browser's localStorage
 In reality, when users clicked the links, malicious JavaScript code contained in the HTML files would execute and steal data from the user's browser localStorage.
 In layman's terms, localStorage is a term that describes a local container in the user's browser where data about a web application is stored.

More than a third of the websites you visit online may include an outdated JavaScript library that's vulnerable to one or more security flaws.
 This is the conclusion of recent research carried out by a team of six scientists from the College of Computer and Information Science at Northeastern University, who scanned over 133,000 domains and found that 37% loaded outdated and insecure JavaScript libraries.
 Scan methodology
 The JavaScript ecosystem is the largest in the world, and the npm repository includes nearly 100,000 libraries. The scan did not cover all, but only 72 of the most popular JavaScript projects, such as jQuery, Angular, Handlebars, Bootstrap, Modernizr, Moment, LoDash, and others.
 To assess the state of each library, researchers also built their own database of vulnerabilities for the selected JavaScript projects.

Since the Cerber Ransomware was first released back in early March of 2016, this ransomware would not only encrypt your files, but would also annoyingly encrypt the file names as well. This made it difficult for users and administrators to determine what files were actually encrypted and restore them from backups.
 While many variants of Cerber have been released over time, this "feature" has always remained the same. That is until today, when both Emsisoft researcher Sarah, otherwise known as xXToffeeXx, and SwiftOnSecurity found a new sample of Cerber that leaves the original filename the same and only appends a random extension as shown below.


 Cerber Encrypted Files


As you can see from the above picture, this new variant will keep the original filename, but now append a random extension to the filename. According to Sarah, this extension will be the same for all files encrypted on a particular machine, but will be different from machine to machine.

A new malicious application tries to disguise itself as the Google Chrome browser to fool victims into entering their payment card details. The app is still active at the time of writing and sends collected user details to an AOL email address.
 Discovered today by MalwareHunter, this application goes above and beyond of what other card stealers have attempted, most of which are half-baked efforts, often easy to recognize as malicious applications thanks to their quirky graphics and misaligned designs.
 This app, named "Betaling - Google Chrome.exe", tries to pass as the Google Chrome browser and does a good job at it. Betaling ("Payment" in Dutch) uses the standard Chrome icon and window layout, complete with an address bar, and even an HTTPS lock icon to trick users they're on a real website.


 Betaling giveaways!

Willem de Groot, a Dutch security expert, is asking owners of defunct or soon-to-be-dead online stores to donate their domains so he can set up honeypots and track credit card stealing malware and other types of cyber-attacks on e-commerce targets.
 De Groot, who is also the co-founder of Byte.nl, a web hosting service, and founder of MageReport, a security scanner for Magento shops, says he needs store owners to donate their former domains because classic honeypots won't work against web malware, and in particular against variants targeting online stores.
 Honeypots are servers that are configured to behave like various types of applications, but they also run monitoring software that logs any attempts to exploit security weaknesses.
 E-commerce honeypots aren't always efficient
 For online stores, setting up a honeypot server implies creating a store from scratch. This is useless, de Groot says, as the store won't have any search engine presence, and attackers could easily detect this.

WikiLeaks dumped 12 new documents today that provide a more in-depth look at the hacking techniques the CIA allegedly used to hack Apple devices, such as Macs and iPhones.
 This dump, which WikiLeaks identifies under the Dark Matter codename, is part of a series of dumps called Vault 7, which WikiLeaks claims are hacking tools obtained from the CIA.
 The first Vault 7 dump, named Year Zero, came to light at the start of March and included wiki pages from the CIA's intranet, containing documentation for some of the CIA's cyber-weapons.
 Dark Matter includes details on lots of EFI/UEFI implants
 Included in this original leak were documents related to CIA's alleged arsenal of OS X and iOS hacking tools. Today's Dark Matter dump provides 12 new documents that contain a lot more information on those tools.

Some of the malicious Android Minecraft mods (ESET)


News of malicious Android apps hosted on the Google Play Store doesn't seem to stop coming these days, as ESET and Zscaler researchers recently disclosed they've reported nearly 100 malicious apps they recently come across.
 The biggest batch comes from ESET security researcher Lukas Stefanko, who says that between March 16 and 21, he reported to Google 87 Android apps posing as Minecraft mods, but which, in reality, contained two malware (adware) strains.
 In total, the researcher says, the apps reached up to 990,000 installs before Google took them down.
 None of the apps contained any Minecraft functionality
 Stefanko says that none of these apps contained any legitimate functionality, being mere vessels for adware. The apps would only work during the installation process, focusing on luring the user into granting them admin privileges.

Security researcher Dylan Ayrey detailed last week a new web-based attack named XSSJacking that combines three other techniques  — Clickjacking, Pastejacking, and Self-XSS — to steal data from careless users.
 Ayrey says XSSJacking can help attackers reach sensitive information for which they would normally need a more complex security flaw, such as a stored XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) or CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery), issues which most websites tend to fix when reported.
 The attack is not fully-automated, as it still relies on social engineering, a reason why many of today's security bug bounty programs won't even consider it as a security flaw, Ayrey told Bleeping Computer in an email.
 Some conditions must be met fo XSSJacking attacks
 For an XSSJacking attack to take place, some conditions must be met, but in hindsight, all attacks, even CSRF and SQL injections, all need one or more special conditions.
 For example, in the case of XSSJacking, the target website must be vulnerable to clickjacking.

A botnet specialized in gift card fraud is using the infrastructure of nearly 1,000 websites to check the balance of several types of electronic gift cards in order to defraud legitimate card owners.
 Distil Networks, a cybersecurity firm specialized in bot attack detection, monitoring, and mitigation, says the botnet, nicknamed GiftGhostBot, has started attacks on February 26, this year.
 Attacks aimed at online stores
 The operators of this botnet aimed their attacks at the infrastructure embedded in some of the targeted websites, most of which are online stores.
 These websites allow their customers to buy products with gift cards, and support end points for interacting with the card's issuer.
 Operators of the GiftGhostBot botnet launch brute-force attacks against these endpoints.

Lots and lots of little crappy ransomware released this week with nothing new or innovative. We do have some interesting Spora stats, lots of new Jigsaw variants, a story on the decline of Locky, and of course an updated decryptor by Fabian Wosar who continues to kick ransomware in the buttocks. Other than that, not really any of significance.
 Contributors and those who provided new ransomware information and stories this week include: @malwrhunterteam, @PolarToffee, @fwosar, @struppigel, @demonslay335,  @malwareforme, @jorntvdw, @FourOctets, DanielGallagher, @campuscodi, @JAMESWT_MHT, @Seifreed, @JakubKroustek, @BleepinComputer, @erpscan, @barklyprotects.

During the past year, Let's Encrypt has issued a total of 15,270 SSL certificates that contained the word "PayPal" in the domain name or the certificate identity.
 Of these, approximately 14,766 (96.7%) were issued for domains that hosted phishing sites, according to an analysis carried out on a small sample of 1,000 domains, by Vincent Lynch, encryption expert for The SSL Store.
 Security experts have warned of Let's Encrypt abuse
 Lynch's analysis comes to confirm some of the fears voiced as early as 2015, around Let's Encrypt's early launch phase.
 Encryption and infosec experts warned that by providing free SSL certificates; phishers, tech support scammers, and other malware authors would flock to obtain free certificates and move their operations on HTTPS domains.

Security researchers discovered a new batch of nine websites infected with malicious JavaScript that steals payment card info from online shoppers.
 Some of them were infected a second time and the script persisted, despite efforts from the researchers to contact the website owners.
 The script is attributed to MageCart Group 12, as per extensive analysis from RiskIQ a threat actor that is changing tactics as their tricks are being published in security reports.
 Code obfuscation does not help
More recent activity linked to this actor was documented by researchers Jacob Pimental and Max Kersten towards the end of January when they published details about two sports events ticket resellers running card skimming code.
 The two researchers noticed that the skimmer is hosted on 'toplevelstatic.com,' which resolves to multiple IP addresses, mostly in Russia.

The number of WhatsApp phishing URLs has skyrocketed in Q4 2019 after a 13,467.6% huge QoQ surge in the number of unique phishing URLs targeting its users being discovered by email security company Vade Secure since Q3 2019.
 Vade Secure's Phishers' Favorites report for Q4 2019 highlights the 25 most impersonated brands in phishing attacks with the list being compiled after examining phishing URLs detected by Vade Secure's technology. 
 "Leveraging data from more than 600 million protected mailboxes worldwide, Vade's machine learning algorithms identify the brands being impersonated as part of its real-time analysis of the URL and page content," Vade Secure says. 
 WhatsApp's 5,020 unique phishing URLs detected by Vade Secure and its ascent as the 5th most impersonated brand in phishing attacks (up 63 spots) was the driving force behind social media brands' increase in the share of URLs used in phishing attacks from 13.1% in Q3 to 24.1% in Q4 2019.
 Vade Secure explains that "the staggering growth in phishing URLs stems primarily from a campaign inviting recipients to the so-called Berbagi WhatsApp group, which advertises pornographic content.
 "Moreover, it appears web hosting provider 000webhost was hacked and used to host the phishing pages.

With the high ransom prices and big payouts of enterprise-targeting ransomware, we now have another ransomware known as Mailto or Netwalker that is compromising enterprise networks and encrypting all of the Windows devices connected to it.
 In August 2019 a new ransomware was spotted in ID Ransomware that was named Mailto based on the extension that was appended to encrypted files.
 It was not known until today when the Australian Toll Group disclosed that their network was attacked by the Mailto ransomware, that we discovered that this ransomware is targeting the enterprise.
 It should be noted that the ransomware has been commonly called the Mailto Ransomware due to the appended extension, but analysis of one of its decryptors indicates that it is named Netwalker.   We will discuss this later in the article.
 The Mailto / Netwalker ransomware

Medicaid coordinated care organization (CCO) Health Share of Oregon today disclosed a data breach exposing the health and personal info of 654,362 individuals following the theft of a laptop owned by its transportation vendor GridWorks IC.
 The non-profit organization is Oregon's largest Medicaid CCO and it serves the Oregon Health Plan (Medicaid) members in Clackamas, Multnomah, and Washington counties.
 "On January 2, 2020, Health Share of Oregon learned that the personal information of its members was located on a laptop stolen from GridWorks IC, Health Share's contracted non-emergent medical transportation (Ride to Care) vendor," says the CCO in a statement issued today.
 "The break-in and theft occurred at GridWorks' office on November 18, 2019. "
 Data breach exposes personal and health information

Attackers are exploiting the hype surrounding this year's Oscar Best Picture nominated movies to infect fans with malware and to bait them to phishing websites designed to steal sensitive info such as credit card details and personal information.
 This method is the perfect way to get around movie fans' defenses seeing that many of them are willing to take down their defenses for a chance to get a free preview, especially given that the 92nd Academy Awards ceremonies are just around the corner on February 9th.
 High-profile TV shows and films are frequently used as lures in social engineering attacks promising early previews either in the form of fake streaming sites or via malicious files disguised as early released copies.
 Over 20 phishing sites use Oscar baits
 Kaspersky researchers who discovered these ongoing attacks "found more than 20 phishing websites and 925 malicious files that were presented as free movies, only to attack the user."
 "The uncovered phishing websites and Twitter accounts gather users’ data and prompt them to carry out a variety of tasks in order to gain access to the desired film," a press release published today says.

The attackers behind the RobbinHood Ransomware are exploiting a vulnerable GIGABYTE driver to install a malicious and unsigned driver into Windows that is used to terminate antivirus and security software.
 When performing a network-wide compromise, ransomware attackers need to push out a ransomware executable as quickly as possible and to as many systems as they can to avoid being detected.
 One protection that can get in their way of a successful attack, though, is antivirus software running on a workstation that removes the ransomware executable before it can be executed.
 To overcome this hurdle, the operators behind the RobbinHood Ransomware are utilizing a custom antivirus killing package that is pushed out to workstations to prepare it for encryption.
 Using trusted drivers to terminate security processes
Most Windows security software processes are protected from being terminated by regular processes and can only be terminated by Kernel drivers, which have the highest permission possible in Windows.
 To better secure Windows, Microsoft added a driver signature enforcement policy that prevents the installation of Windows Kernel drivers unless they have been cosigned by Microsoft.

The U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) today issued a notification to raise awareness among victims of the Quantum Stresser Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) for-hire service operated by David Bukoski.
 DDoS-for-hire services known as booters or stressers are used by malicious actors, pranksters, or hacktivists to launch large-scale DDoS cyberattacks against a targeted site or online service, triggering a denial of service that leads to the service being taken down or working a lot slower than usual.
 "Due to the large number of potential victims in this case, Chief U.S. District Judge Timothy M. Burgess issued an order directing the government to employ alternative victim notification procedures so that any member of the community at large who believes they may be a crime victim is made aware of their potential rights," the DoJ statement says.
 "The government is asking that members of the community who believe they may be a victim of Bukoski’s criminal activities, to please contact (907) 271-3041 to reach the Victim-Witness Unit at the U.S. Attorney’s Office, District of Alaska."
 This notification was the result of a motion for alternative victim notification filed on February 3 which also says that there are "plans to notify –   to the extent possible – those ISPs providing services to victim networks, who may be able to conduct additional notification of their own customers. "
 The DoJ has scheduled a restitution hearing on May 5, 2020, at 10:30 A.M. in Anchorage.

Android users are targeted in a phishing campaign that will infect their devices with the Anubis banking Trojan that can steal financial information from more than 250 banking and shopping applications.
 The campaign uses a devious method to get the potential victims to install the malware on their devices: it asks them to enable Google Play Protect while actually disabling it after being granted permissions on the device.
 To deliver the malware, the attackers use a malicious link embedded within the phishing email that will download an APK file camouflaged as an invoice as Cofense found.
 After being asked if he wants to use Google Play Protect and installing the downloaded APK, the victim's device will be infected with the Anubis Trojan.

 Google Play Protect used as cover (Cofense)
 Targets over 250 financial applications

Three more ransomware families have created sites that are being used to leak the stolen data of non-paying victims and further illustrates why all ransomware attacks must be considered data breaches.
 Ever since Maze created their "news" site to publish stolen data of their victims who choose not to pay, other ransomware actors such as Sodinokibi/REvil, Nemty, and DoppelPaymer have been swift to follow.
 Over the past two days, BleepingComputer has learned of another three ransomware families who have now launched their data leak sites, which are listed below.
 While we have been saying it for a long time, with the continued release of data leak sites, ransomware attacks must be treated as data breaches now that the personal and private data of employees is being published online.
 To make matters worse, other threat actors are taking the data exposed in these leaks and selling it on hacker forums so it can be utilized in other attacks.
 Nefilim Ransomware

A modular malware with worm capabilities exploits known vulnerabilities in servers running ElasticSearch, Hadoop, Redis, Spring, Weblogic, ThinkPHP, and SqlServer to spread from one server to another and mine for Monero cryptocurrency.
 Systemctl.exe, the worm module of the malware named PsMiner by the 360 Total Security researchers, is a Windows binary written in the Go language which bundles all the exploit modules used to hack into vulnerable servers it can find on the Internet.
 Besides the exploits, PsMiner's worm module also has the capability to brute force its way in, whenever it finds targets that uses weak or default credentials, as well as crack user credentials using an additional brute force password cracking component.
 Once it manages to infiltrate a victim's computer, PsMiner will execute a PowerShell command which downloads a WindowsUpdate.ps1 malicious payload, the malware's master module designed to drop the Monero miner as part of the final infection stage.


 The infection process


 The malware will also copy the malicious WindowsUpdate.ps1 script to the Windows Temp folder and will create an "Update service for Windows Service" scheduled task designed to re-launch the main malware module every 10 minutes to help it keep persistence on the compromised system.

Caching servers commonly deployed with big-name services will often cache the incorrect page content, including personal details, when the user accesses a non-existent resource, such as CSS or JavaScript files.
 This issue, nicknamed a "web cache deception attack," was discovered by Israeli security researcher Omer Gil, who says it affects many online services.
 Three services affected, possibly more
Gil, who works as an information security team leader at EY Hacktics Advanced Security Center in Tel Aviv, says he already contacted three major companies affected by the issue.
 All three companies fixed their issues. PayPal is one of the three, while the other two asked the researcher to refrain from publishing their name.
 Bleeping Computer has reached out to Gil and inquired if the attack vector he discovered is a widespread issue among today's web services.

Bad news from malware-land after security researchers from IBM reported today they'd discovered the first samples of version 4.0 of the infamous and highly-active Dridex banking trojan.
 One of the lesser known things about computer viruses is the fact that malware is very similar to normal software, often going through the same development cycles and receiving constant updates.
 While most malware operators strive to keep as much of their source code and operational details hidden, the Dridex crew has always embedded the malware’s version number in its source, which, in turn, has permitted researchers to easily track its evolution.
 Dridex reaches v4 two years after launch
 This version number included in Dridex binaries and configuration files has allowed researchers to create a timeline of major Dridex versions. For example, based on the version numbers, Dridex v1 launched in late 2014 and only lasted up until the first days of 2015.

A researcher has discovered what he calls a "logic vulnerability" that allowed him to create a Python script that is fully capable of bypassing Google's reCAPTCHA fields using another Google service, the Speech Recognition API.
 The researcher, who goes online only by the name of East-EE, released proof-of-concept code on GitHub.
 ReBreakCaptcha vulnerability still unpatched
East-EE has named this attack ReBreakCaptcha, and he says he discovered this vulnerability in 2016. Today, when he went public with his research, he said the vulnerability was still unpatched.
 The researcher was not clear if he reported the bug to Google.

The Crypt0L0cker ransomware, otherwise known as Torrentlocker or Teerac, was a common ransomware infection that mostly targeted Australia and European countries in 2014. Towards the middle of 2015, though, this ransomware slowly started dying off to the point that it was hardly distributed anymore.
 Fast forward to the beginning of February 2017 where we are now seeing Crypt0L0cker making a strong come back and targeting European countries once again.
 Crypt0L0cker Campaigns Targeting European Countries
 Over the past few days, I have been receiving a lot of requests for help in decrypting files encrypted by Crypt0L0cker. To see if there was a resurgence in activity, I checked the ID-Ransomware site and saw that towards the end of January Crypt0L0cker went from a small amount of submissions to the their site a day, to close to a 100.

Payment card data of thousands of online shoppers has been stolen at checkout via malicious JavaScript code cybercriminals embedded in seven websites and which continues to collect and deliver the information the crooks.
 Among the websites actively leaking customers' sensitive data to an unauthorized third party is FILA UK, likely since November 2018, when it was compromised.
 Thieving script active on multiple websites
 It is estimated that at least 5,600 shoppers of FILA sportswear had their payment and personal details stolen by now. At the moment, every new customer of the website has the same fate.

 Six more websites in the US put their customer's card data at risk just like FILA's UK website.

In late March 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed UPS- and invoice-themed campaigns delivering Emotet via links leading to ZIP archives containing macro-laden Word documents or JavaScript. This is a departure from its historical tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs); most commonly, campaigns have leveraged macro document attachments or links leading to macro documents. FireEye Threat Intelligence also observed changes in the way Emotet communicates through HTTP POST requests with its command and control (C&C) servers. These changes were likely made to evade host and network-based detection mechanisms, although it would be easy for security product vendors to adapt to these changes.

Massive IMAP-based password-spraying attacks successfully breached Microsoft Office 365 and G Suite accounts, circumventing multi-factor authentication (MFA) according to an analysis by Proofpoint.
 This technique takes advantage of the fact that the legacy authentication IMAP protocol bypasses MFA, allowing malicious actors to perform credential stuffing attacks against assets that would have been otherwise protected.
 As noted by Proofpoint's Information Protection Research Team in a recent report, during a "recent six-month study of major cloud service tenants, Proofpoint researchers observed massive attacks leveraging legacy protocols and credential dumps to increase the speed and effectiveness of brute force account compromises at scale."
 72% of cloud tenants targeted at least once
 Their analysis unearthed the fact that around 60% of all Microsoft Office 365 and G Suite tenants have been targeted using IMAP-based password-spraying attacks and, as a direct result, approximately 25% of G Suite and Office 365 tenants that were attacked also experienced a successful breach.

Intel fixed 20 security vulnerabilities in the Intel Graphics Driver for Windows which would lead to escalation of privilege, denial of service, or information disclosure if exploited by attackers with local access to the system under attack.
 According to the QSR advisory published 2 days ago, Intel issued multiple updates for its into graphics driver for Windows designed to mitigate the vulnerabilities found by internal and external security researchers.
 Out of the 20 vulnerabilities found in the Intel Graphics Driver for Windows, two were rated as high risk with CVSS Base Scores of 7.3 and 8.2, allowing local attackers to execute arbitrary code after escalating their privileges.
 Attackers require local access to exploit Intel Graphics Driver flaws
To be more exact, the security issues tracked as CVE-2018-12214 and CVE-2018-12216 could lead to an escalation of privileges for local users following a potential memory corruption in Kernel Mode Driver and insufficient input validation in Kernel Mode Driver, respectively.
 The rest of the 18 vulnerabilities patched by Intel were rated as low and medium risk, all of them being exploitable via local attack vectors with low attack complexity and no user interaction needed—the only ones who would need the user's attention are CVE-2018-18090 and CVE-2018-18091 that would trigger a DoS state.

 As detailed in the advisory, "Intel recommends that users of Intel Graphics Driver for Windows update to versions 10.18.x.5059 (aka 15.33.x.5059), 10.18.x.5057 (aka 15.36.x.5057), 20.19.x.5063 (aka 15.40.x.5063

 Attackers require local access to exploit Intel Graphics Driver flaws
To be more exact, the security issues tracked as CVE-2018-12214 and CVE-2018-12216 could lead to an escalation of privileges for local users following a potential memory corruption in Kernel Mode Driver and insufficient input validation in Kernel Mode Driver, respectively.
 The rest of the 18 vulnerabilities patched by Intel were rated as low and medium risk, all of them being exploitable via local attack vectors with low attack complexity and no user interaction needed—the only ones who would need the user's attention are CVE-2018-18090 and CVE-2018-18091 that would trigger a DoS state.

 As detailed in the advisory, "Intel recommends that users of Intel Graphics Driver for Windows update to versions 10.18.x.5059 (aka 15.33.x.5059), 10.18.x.5057 (aka 15.36.x.5057), 20.19.x.5063 (aka 15.40.x.5063

Google added a new Admin console option for G Suite admins designed to help them disable telephony options as two-factor authentication (2FA) methods for G Suite accounts in their domain, preventing users from using SMS and voice codes when authenticating.
 According to a G Suite Help Center support document, 2FA—also known as 2-Step Verification (2SV)—"requires users to verify their identity through something they know (such as a password) plus something they have (such as a physical key or access code delivered to a device). It’s also called multi-factor authentication (MFA) or 2-factor authentication (2FA). "
Once enabled for an account, 2FA (configured to work with text/voice message codes, the Google Authenticator app, or with hardware second factors like security keys) will protect it from unauthorized access by creating an extra defense designed to block malicious actors from logging in using stolen credentials.
 SMS and voice 2FA considered insecure

Medical IoT (IoMT) devices are left exposed to attacks because of outdated or legacy operating systems which, in many cases, are very easy to hack into and expose a throve of sensitive patient data, highly sought over on the black market.
 In one instance, researchers from Check Point Research were able to find an ultrasound machine running a Windows 2000 OS which no longer receives security patches, leaving the machine vulnerable to a multitude of attacks.
 The researchers demonstrated that, after infiltrating the ultrasound device by exploiting one of the vulnerabilities that impacted it, potential attackers could download the patient records stored within, edit and replace data on the machine, as well as infect it with ransomware allowing them to request a ransom to be paid to restore the medical data.

 While this is just a single example of what threat actors can do if they gain access to IoMT devices that use legacy operating systems with numerous and easy to exploit vulnerabilities, it definitely shows the significant damages which attacks targeting health-related data can inflict.
 Just last year, the UK Department of Health and Social Care announced that all National Health Service (NHS) computer systems will be transitioned to Windows 10 following more than a third of all NHS trusts being hit by WannaCry, with the attacks leading to the cancelation of roughly 7,000 medical appointments across the UK—including critical operations.
 Medical data was also the target of threat actors which managed to breach the IT systems of Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) and steal the data of approximately 1.5 million citizens.

A new Ransomware-as-a-Service called Yatron is being promoted on Twitter that plans on using the EternalBlue and DoublePulsar exploits to spread to other computer on a network. This ransomware will also attempt to delete encrypted files if a payment has not been made in 72 hours.
 BleepingComputer was first notified about the Yatron RaaS by a security researcher who goes by the name A Shadow. Since then, the actor behind this ransomware has strangely been promoting the service by tweeting to various ransomware and security researchers as shown below.

 Tweet from Ransomware Developer
 After seeing one of these tweets, BleepingComputer was able to find a sample on VirusTotal and with the help of Michael Gillespie, we started to examine the source code of the ransomware.

The Oregon Department of Human Services (DHS) announced that roughly 2 million emails with Protected Health Information (PHI) from more than 350,000 customers have been potentially exposed after 9 employee mailboxes were compromised in a spear phishing attack.
 According to the Oregon DHS, its Enterprise Security Office Cyber Security team was the one which determined that the email boxes were breached on January 28, 2019.
 DHS also said that the attackers were stopped from further accessing the hacked mailboxes by resetting the passwords and that an investigation was started to review all the information that might have been exposed, as well as to pinpoint the exact "number of impacted records that might contain personal information of clients receiving services from DHS."
 Forensic review of the data breach ongoing
After the attack was successfully stopped, "The agency has hired an outside entity, IDExperts, to perform a forensic review to clarify the number and identities of Oregonians whose information was exposed, and the specific kinds of information involved."
 DHS states that the PHI impacted in the data breach "was accessible to an unauthorized person" and that the information "may include first and last names, addresses, dates of birth, Social Security numbers, case number and other information used to administer DHS programs."
 Also, "The department cannot confirm that any clients’ personal information was acquired from its email system or used inappropriately.

During the second day of Pwn2Own Vancouver 2019, competitors successfully pwned the Mozilla Firefox and Microsoft Edge web browsers, as well as VMware's Workstation client, earning a total of $270,000 in cash awards.
 As part of the first event, the Fluoroacetate team targeted and successfully exploited Mozilla's Firefox web browser with a kernel escalation using a JIT bug and an out-of-bounds write in the Windows kernel.
 The same team also tried their hand against Microsoft's Edge web browser with a VMware escape and a kernel escalation, using an exploit chain combining "a type confusion in Edge, a race condition in the windows kernel, and an out-of-bounds write in VMware Workstation.
 They started from within the VMware Workstation client and visited a specially crafted web page using Microsoft Edge to escape the VM and execute code on the hypervisor.
 The two exploitation demos earned Fluoroacetate $180,000 during the second day, which, combined with their previous $160,000 earnings from the previous day, brings them to a total of $340,000.

 Niklas Baumstark also targeted Mozilla's Firefox web browser and successfully hacked it using a JIT bug chained with a logic bug to escape the browser's sandbox, earning $40,000 in the process.
